title: How to Choose a Lubricant for Masturbation & Sex

steps.title: Use water-based lube for all your masturbation and sexual needs.
steps.content: Use water-based lube for all your masturbation and sexual needs. Water-based lube can be used for just about anything—it’s perfect for any kind of masturbation, and it works great with all of your favorite toys. You can also lube up your condoms without worrying about them breaking later on. Unfortunately, water-based lube washes away easily, so it’s not a great option if you’re a fan of shower or pool sex. [1] X Research source Many water-based lubes are pretty affordable. Some common water-based brands are Astroglide , Liquid Silk , and KY Jelly . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Grab some silicone-based lube for longer sessions.
steps.content: Grab some silicone-based lube for longer sessions. As the name suggests, silicone-based lube isn’t made with water, so you don’t have to worry about it washing away. It’s great option for shower, anal, or pool sex, and it won’t rub or wash away. Unfortunately, this product tends to be on the thicker side, and may be a little uncomfortable to use with your toys. Don’t use silicone-based lube if you use silicone-based sex toys—they’ll damage your toys. Wet Platinum , Eros , and ID Millennium are some well-known silicone lube brands. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Pick oil-based lube for massages or penile masturbation, but not condoms.
steps.content: Pick oil-based lube for massages or penile masturbation, but not condoms. Oil-based lube is the slickest product of all, but also the most finicky. It’s a great option for penile masturbation, or if you’re giving your partner an intimate massage. Unfortunately, your body can’t absorb oil, so you shouldn’t use it to lube up your vagina. [4] X Research source Oil-based lubes will also eat through latex, so don’t use them with any latex condoms. [5] X Research source Some oil-based lubes are listed as “massage oil.” In general, oil-based lube shouldn’t be used for sex.

steps.title: Play around with warming or cooling lubes for a unique sensation.
steps.content: Play around with warming or cooling lubes for a unique sensation. Warming lubes make your skin feel hotter, and can really boost your moments of pleasure and intimacy. Similarly, cooling lubes make your skin feel colder, and can help your masturbation and sex feel way more stimulating. [6] X Research source Cooling lubes work great with glass or metal toys. Some people find warming lubes a little irritating. Test out a small amount of this lube on a tiny section of skin before using too much of it! [7] X Research source

steps.title: You can use water- and silicone-based lubes with condoms.
steps.content: You can use water- and silicone-based lubes with condoms. These varieties won’t break down any of the material. Unfortunately, oil-based lubes will break down your condoms, and should only be used for massages or penile masturbation. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Use polyurethane condoms with alternate, oil-based lubes.
steps.content: Use polyurethane condoms with alternate, oil-based lubes. Unlike latex condoms, the polyurethane variety won’t break down or split when used with oil-based lubes. If you’re experimenting with different kinds of lubes, stock up on this type of condom ahead of time. [9] X Research source

steps.title: You can use coconut oil as lube, but not with condoms.
steps.content: You can use coconut oil as lube, but not with condoms. Coconut oil is a great option if you have a lot of allergies, or if you aren’t a fan of traditional lubes. Unfortunately, it doesn’t work well with latex condoms.

steps.title: Try vitamin E oil in place of traditional lube if you aren’t using a condom.
steps.content: Try vitamin E oil in place of traditional lube if you aren’t using a condom. Pick up a bottle of this oil from your local pharmacy and give it a try. However, don’t use it with a condom—unfortunately, natural oils like vitamin E can break down condoms. [10] X Trustworthy Source Michigan Medicine The University of Michigan's medical center, which provides patient care, supports research, and educates the public on health topics Go to source You can also try vitamin E oil as a suppository. You typically need a prescription to get this, though.

steps.title: Spread your lube around your vagina in small amounts.
steps.content: Spread your lube around your vagina in small amounts. Squeeze out a grape-sized amount of water-based lube or a blueberry-sized amount of silicone- or oil-based lube onto your palm. Rub it over both the inner and outer lips of your vagina, as well as your clit. If needed, squeeze out and apply more lube as you need to.

steps.title: Apply lube over your skin.
steps.content: Apply lube over your skin. Rub the lube into any part of your skin where you plan on being massaged or pleasured. Start with a grape- or blueberry-sized amount of lube, using more product as needed.

steps.title: Rub lube all over your toys.
steps.content: Rub lube all over your toys. You don’t want any friction when you’re busy playing with yourself or your partner. Apply the lube all over the toy, so your playtime is as comfortable and smooth as possible. It’s a lot easier to feel turned on when your toys are lubed up.

steps.title: Spread lube over your penis when you’re masturbating or having sex.
steps.content: Spread lube over your penis when you’re masturbating or having sex. Masturbation can lead to some uncomfortable friction—that’s where lube comes in! Rub some lube up and down the length of your penis so you can stay comfortable while you pleasure yourself. [11] X Research source Lubing up before sex also makes things a lot more comfortable for you and your partner. A grape-sized amount is usually enough if you’re working with water-based lube, while a blueberry-sized amount will get the job done with silicone- or oil-based lube.

steps.title: Watch out for a small handful of toxic ingredients.
steps.content: Watch out for a small handful of toxic ingredients. Chlorhexidine gluconate, parabens, cyclopentasiloxane, cyclotetrasiloxane, and cyclomethicone are all connected with different health concerns, like killing off healthy vaginal bacteria, causing irritation and rashes, and other issues. Ingredients like parabens, cyclomethicone, cyclopentasiloxane, and cyclotetrasiloxane are also connected with more serious concerns, like fertility and endocrine issues, along with other reproductive problems. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Stay away from vague flavors or fragrance.
steps.content: Stay away from vague flavors or fragrance. Some bottles of lube include ingredients like “fragrance,” “aroma,” or “flavor,” which aren’t great for your body. There’s no way to know what ingredients are these vague categories. In several cases, “fragrances” and “aromas” include toxins, carcinogens, and other bad ingredients. [13] X Research source The World Health Organization tested a variety of different lubes. You can see the results here: https://www.womensvoices.org/osmolality-ph-properties-commercial-lubricants .

steps.title: Pick out a lube made with hydroxyethyl cellulose.
steps.content: Pick out a lube made with hydroxyethyl cellulose. A lot of lubes can slow down sperm, and aren’t ideal if you’re hoping to get pregnant. Hydroxyethylcellulose-based lubes act a lot like vaginal mucus, and are a safe option if you’re planning for a family. [14] X Research source
